Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
I trust in the knowledge and integrity of those who say that it isn't much of a security threat.
My opinion to hardfork, even though a pain is the ass, is based on the idea that it is probably a good habit for me to get into and to demonstrate LABS commitment to security.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: That being said, I don't know how much of a difficulty a hf would be on others, or the level of threat, if any, posed.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Was thinking maybe make a short `reasons for hf` and `reasons against hf` list people could add to so that people could make an informed vote?
ie:
`against hf`
-  acceptable security risk (example)
-  would cause difficulties for current projects, LABS, pools, exchanges (example)
`for hf`
- set a precedent (example)
- show future projects and investors a commitment to security (example)

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: Has someone proposed the full scope of the hf in question? Awaiting all claims possible to make sure the end point addresses gets a fat 0 on the new chain? Awaiting a certain amount to be identified as stolen before picking when to hf? New NN pubkeys etc are all well and good, restoring lost funds is great though messy... i think the real question is if the hf scope should include the foundations of using votes to govern the code commits. I think the NN operators need to provide consensus for all commits to the Komodo family of repositories.

Author: Alright#0419

Author: Alright#0419
Content: deactivate them all by default with ac_cc, and implicitly activate any the chain needs via ac_ccenable. Not sure how this will work for existing chains, but activating a bunch of CCs you don't actually plan to use is not a good idea

Content:
OUR, DION, KMDICE, CCL, SEC, EQL, COQUI, AXO, ILN, RICK, MORTY

chains with ac_cc and no ac_ccenable
